children.text: In early June, Charles Combs traveled 50 miles to attend a free pop-up health clinic in Charleston, West Virginia, to have some teeth extracted.
He pulled down his facemask, revealing a patchwork of missing teeth, and pointed to a damaged tooth in the center that needed to be removed.
A resident of Lincoln County, Combs said he‚Äôs disabled from a head injury he sustained years ago as a laborer and does not have health or dental insurance. He told
The Lever
he has resorted to extracting his own teeth because dental care is too expensive.
‚ÄúI‚Äôve been doing them myself,‚Äù Combs said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been offing them out with a hammer and a knotter.‚Äù

children.productTitle: NEW PODCAST: The Fed Hates You (Also, How To Build A Third Party)
children.productDescription: On this week‚Äôs Lever Time, David explores how the Federal Reserve is approaching inflation all wrong, exposes the big problem with the January 6 hearings, and interviews Kendra Brooks and David Zuckerman about winning third- party campaigns.

children.text: Combs was sitting on bleachers in a school gymnasium that had been temporarily converted into a COVID-safe dental clinic. A maze of white tents, connected to one another by snaking air ducts, spread across the tarp-covered floor, looking like something out of the film
E.T.
Some volunteers nearby checked patients in and brought them to their appointments, while others emptied out buckets of blood and hazardous materials.

Combs was one of hundreds of patients who had congregated here, at Charleston‚Äôs Bible Center School, to attend a Remote Area Medical (RAM) clinic designed to offer free medical, dental, and vision services to people in need. The operation was taking place just a few miles away from the riverfront home of
Sen. Joe Manchin (D-W.Va.)
Manchin
last
year

blocked Democrats‚Äô plan to expand Medicare to provide all seniors with dental and vision benefits, arguing it would be too expensive. Manchin‚Äôs opposition was a victory for the health insurance industry, which
ran TV ads
praising him for protecting their lucrative privatized Medicare plans.

But the Charleston clinic made clear just how badly people need such care ‚Äî and not just seniors, and not just West Virginians. Combs, for instance, is still in his 50s, while the clinic saw patients of all ages driving hours from Ohio, Kentucky, and Virginia.

The RAM clinic hinted at the kind of universal health care system America could have, if not for senators like Manchin and their health care industry donors. The organization doesn‚Äôt ask patients about what its team calls the ‚Äúthree I‚Äôs‚Äù: identification, income, or insurance. Patients are treated with kindness, compassion, and professionalism ‚Äî and fairly quickly. All services are free.

But instead of being replicated from coast to coast, this vital work is relegated to a small operation that many don‚Äôt know about. RAM, which has been operating for more than three decades, reported just $6.4 million in revenue in 2020, and only has roughly three dozen clinics planned for this year. The organization relies in large part on volunteers, especially volunteer physicians, nurses, dentists, and hygienists.

The problems RAM is working to address are staggering. Some patients at the Charleston clinic were living in constant pain, due to a lack of professional dental care. Their ailments would have been easier to manage or less severe had they received care sooner ‚Äî if only they had been able to afford it.
Combs, and his self-directed dental surgery, illustrates the issue. ‚ÄúWhen I had this last one pulled, it cost me $400,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs too much.‚Äù
‚ÄúAll We Ask Of The Patients Is Time And Patience‚Äù
Founded in 1985, RAM was originally designed to provide health care services to people living in
inaccessible regions
, like the Amazon rainforest. The nonprofit quickly
started receiving requests
to hold events in the United States.

RAM still holds international clinics and hosts events in areas affected by natural disasters, but its work is primarily centered around filling gaps here at home. The organization hosts two- and three-day clinics all over the country, where patients receive medical, dental, and vision services free-of-charge. Glasses are made on site, same-day.
Patients can start signing up at venues at midnight the night before clinics start, and many stay in their car until it‚Äôs their time for care. Doors open at 5:30 a.m., and services start at 6 a.m.

children.caption: Patients lining up for the Charleston RAM clinic. (Andrew Perez)

children.text: ‚ÄúWe take care of the acute problem ‚Äî if somebody needs to have an eye exam, they can‚Äôt afford to go to the doctor, or they can‚Äôt afford their deductible,‚Äù said Vicki Gregg, RAM‚Äôs clinic manager, as she was overseeing the Charleston event. ‚ÄúOur clinics are first come, first served. All we ask of the patients is their time and patience, and we will take care of them to the best of our ability.‚Äù

Based in Rockford, Tennessee, RAM goes where they are invited to partner with community health groups. So far this year, RAM has held clinics in Florida, Kentucky, North Carolina, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Tennessee, and Virginia. They‚Äôre scheduled to host more events in California, Georgia, Iowa, Nevada, New York, and Oklahoma.
Since

, RAM has worked with West Virginia Health Right, a local charitable clinic, to host the Charleston event. Patients at the June event were asked to choose between either vision or dental, while every attendee was offered medical services.

children.calloutText:
HELP US GROW, FOLLOW US ON SOCIAL MEDIA:

‚Ä¢ Facebook
‚Ä¢ Instagram
‚Ä¢ YouTube

children.text: ‚ÄúThe majority is dental ‚Äî always,‚Äù said Gregg. ‚ÄúDental is about 65 percent, roughly. Vision comes in second. Medical, we‚Äôre looking at about five to eight percent.‚Äù
It‚Äôs easy to understand why dental and vision services would be in such high demand: Neither Medicare nor private health insurance plans cover routine dental or vision care. State Medicaid plans
generally only cover
dental extractions or emergencies, and only
limited
vision services if they do at all. Private dental insurance plans and Medicare Advantage plans that offer dental coverage do not in reality cover much, because they often include
annual
maximums of $1,000 or $2,000; once the insurer pays that much, you‚Äôre on your own.
Millions of Americans
suffer
from visual impairment or blindness due to not having glasses, which are exponentially
more expensive
in the U.S. than in poorer countries. Meanwhile,
more than a quarter
of American seniors end up with no remaining natural teeth. The dental crisis is
particularly acute
in West Virginia ‚Äî according to 2021
data
, the state has the highest percentage of seniors with no natural teeth of anywhere in the country.
That worsening crisis did not deter Manchin from blocking an expansion of dental coverage: While consistently voting for
ever-larger military budgets
, he said he
opposed
‚Äúspending trillions more on new and expanded government programs,‚Äù calling it ‚Äúthe definition of fiscal insanity.‚Äù
‚ÄúMy Teeth Hurt Every Day ‚Äî What I Got Left‚Äù

Robert sat on the Bible Center School‚Äôs gym bleachers, waiting nervously for his dental appointment. He had come to the RAM clinic to get a broken tooth extracted ‚Äî but he needs the rest out, too.

‚ÄúI was sent a couple of months ago to an oral surgeon to have my teeth removed,‚Äù said Robert, who did not give his real name. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre all bad. They want $3,000 to remove them. I‚Äôm on Disability Social Security, and I don‚Äôt have $3,000. And one of my teeth is broken in the back, and it‚Äôs cutting my jaw, the side of my jaw really bad.‚Äù

Robert, who was born and raised in Charleston, said he can‚Äôt work due to several health issues ‚Äî he has heart disease and high blood pressure, making it hard to stand for long periods of time. He‚Äôs also bipolar and said he is on many medications.

children.caption: A RAM van at the Charleston clinic. (Andrew Perez)

children.text: He said he lives in constant pain due to the state of his teeth, and doesn‚Äôt have the money to take care of them.

If it weren‚Äôt for the clinic, Robert said, ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs nothing I really could do. I have no way of raking up that kind of money. Ain‚Äôt no way. With bills, rent, car insurance, food, gasoline, there‚Äôs nothing there to save with what I make a month. I couldn‚Äôt afford it. I can‚Äôt save money.‚Äù
‚ÄúMy teeth hurt every day ‚Äî what I got left,‚Äù he added. ‚ÄúSo I have to deal with them.‚Äù
Patients often travel long distances to RAM events. Some patients at the Charleston clinic were from Kentucky, where the dental crisis is
roughly
as bad
as West Virginia‚Äôs ‚Äî and potentially even worse, by some estimates.

Laura McDavid and her teenaged son drove around 80 miles to the RAM clinic from northeast Kentucky, at the urging of a local social services organization. She said she‚Äôs suffering from a degenerative bone disease and needs to get all of her teeth removed.
‚ÄúI‚Äôve always had perfect teeth until the last probably four years,‚Äù she said.

McDavid said she hoped the clinic would mean being ‚Äúon the road to hopefully getting all of them pulled so I can get dentures.‚Äù She said some of her teeth must be removed surgically, ‚Äúbut the least number of them that they have to do, the better.‚Äù
Working as a grocery store cashier, McDavid said she doesn‚Äôt have health or dental coverage. ‚ÄúI work a minimum-wage job,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúWe have no insurance.‚Äù
‚ÄúI Fell In Love‚Äù

The Charleston clinic was manned by RAM‚Äôs small staff, plus dozens of volunteers. They did this work because they wanted to help people who are in pain ‚Äî and because they believe everyone deserves to be treated with dignity.

‚ÄúWhat got me was [RAM‚Äôs mission] to prevent pain and alleviate suffering,‚Äù said Ronnie Hatfield, RAM‚Äôs senior volunteer coordinator in an interview before the clinic. ‚ÄúI wanted to be a part of an organization that, with everything they do, they try to help people. I went to one clinic to kind of try it out and see how I liked it, and I fell in love.‚Äù

children.caption: Entrance to the RAM dental clinic in Charleston. (Andrew Perez)

children.text: Loni Maughan, who previously worked for RAM, traveled from southeastern Ohio to volunteer at the Charleston event.

‚ÄúPeople have to put their health care on the backburner sometimes, and there‚Äôs major trickle-down effects when that happens,‚Äù she said in between guiding patients to various treatment spaces. ‚ÄúSo when RAM comes in and is able to help fill that gap, they‚Äôre not just helping that person for the day, but they‚Äôre helping them to really pick themselves up in lots of different areas ‚Äî for their family, for their community, for their job. That‚Äôs why I come out to volunteer with them, and to step in where I can to help the patients and help them get the care they need.‚Äù

Andrea Board, a longtime surgical technician in operating rooms, drove from Winchester, Virginia, to help out at the RAM event. ‚ÄúI still have family here,‚Äù she said while walking through the vision clinic, a darkened room with stained-glass windows where people sat quietly waiting for eye exams. ‚ÄúI wanted to give back to the community where my family is deeply rooted.‚Äù

Board said she‚Äôs volunteered at several RAM events because ‚Äúthey don‚Äôt discriminate, they don‚Äôt ask questions, it‚Äôs very non-judgmental, and they‚Äôre here to help everybody who needs help.‚Äù
‚ÄúSometimes, this is the only health care that people will get for the entire year,‚Äù she noted, adding, ‚ÄúI love the fact that people get these new glasses that are life changing.‚Äù

Christy Barnett volunteered at the RAM clinic as a representative of a local church, helping feed RAM‚Äôs staff and volunteers. She said she chose to volunteer because of both religious conviction and a personal connection, explaining that West Virginia Health Right ‚Äî the community health group partnering with RAM ‚Äî helped her get her life back following a mental health crisis.

‚ÄúThey were there for me at a time that was my darkest, when I had no insurance and nowhere else to turn,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThey treated me with dignity and respect, they gave me prescriptions, and had it not been for them, I don‚Äôt know that I would be as strong as I am today.‚Äù
‚ÄúA Wonderful Thing In A Harsh World‚Äù
Melina, who only gave her first name, traveled from Conneaut, Ohio. She sat on a stage near the vision clinic for a long interview with the RAM communications team.

‚Äú‚Äã‚ÄãYears ago, I thought I had a career with a major oil company,‚Äù said Melina. ‚ÄúI worked for them for over a decade, and then I realized they don't care about you. So now I think everybody should find what they're good at, and do it. Financially, it's rough. It's better, though. But it means that there's gaps in things like bank accounts.‚Äù
Melina said she first went to a RAM clinic shortly before the start of the COVID-19 pandemic, at a mall in Ashtabula, Ohio.

‚ÄúI had a tooth that desperately needed to be taken out, and I was in excruciating pain,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúEveryone was kind to everyone. I just have never seen people treat indigent people in particular with this much care, regard, and decency. They just treated us like we were valuable human beings and deserve good care.‚Äù

While she had been scared to have the tooth removed, Melina said the procedure ended up being ‚Äúalmost pleasant‚Äù and ‚Äúthe best dental care I ever had.‚Äù She said the Ashtabula RAM clinic helped set her up with an appointment to get bloodwork, and those lab results revealed she had anemia and needed to race to the emergency room.
‚ÄúI think they saved my life,‚Äù she said.

Melina said she went back to another Ashtabula RAM event this year and got a filling, and she traveled around five hours to attend the Charleston event for a dental cleaning and women‚Äôs health services.
‚ÄúWhen I get everything else fixed, I‚Äôm coming back to volunteer,‚Äù she said, calling RAM ‚Äúa wonderful thing in a harsh world.‚Äù
